title: As a non-Christian, do you like Christian music? - Quora

response.answer_text: I grew up with classical music in the house, and two parents who sang in both church choir and in the community choral ensemble. They sang everything from the obligatory Handel’s Messiah every Christmas, to Milhaud’s King David (we got Vincent Price to do the narration), to Mozart’s Grand Mass in C, to Beethoven’s Missa Solemnis (of which my father, a tenor, said, “That deaf bastard was lucky he never had to sing this!”, referring to the very difficult ending of the Gloria). . . So I grew up with plenty of Christian music in that sense, and I enjoy it still. As for contemporary Christian music. . . I used to have to drive across the western United States, several times a year, in a pickup truck with a tapedeck and a radio. And by the time I’d hit New Mexico, I’d usually played all my tapes and desperately needed a change. . . but there were long stretches of New Mexico where the only radio stations I could get were either country music stations (which, at the time, were all playing LeAnn Rimes’s “How Do I Live” fifty bazillion times a day), or this statewide network of contemporary Christian radio stations called M88. So sometimes, for a change, I’d find an M88 station and roll through Moriarty or Gallup or Tucumcari cranking, oh, Plankeye and Third Day and Rebecca St. James and World Wide Message Tribe, back in the day. . . . . . and what always struck me was that it all sounded exactly the same as what was on the secular pop/rock stations. You could match up almost every song on Maximum 88 with a close analogue on the secular charts. It was like Darwin contemplating Australian mammals. Third Day sounded to me like they’d gone through Creed’s garbage looking for songs (and Creed always sounded to me like they’d gone through Pearl Jam’s garbage looking for their songs). When there was a brief revival of swing music, with secular artists like the Brian Setzer Orchestra and the Squirrel Nut Zippers getting airplay and charting a few hits. . . the Christian music industry came up with the W’s, who obligedly cranked out a swingin’ single whose chorus went “You are the Devil and the Devil is BAD!” repeatedly. There was Christian grunge, Christian female singer-songwriter Lilith Fair-type stuff, and one night at 3 in the morning I came across Christian death metal. (Lyrics: grraggghhrrr rrhgraaggghhh aargghhraaggg JESUS ghhraawwrrgg!!!) At the time, what struck me about the whole listening experience was that the industry was taking what is, supposedly, the most revolutionary message in the history of mankind, and packaging it so that it perfectly conformed to the standards of the world. Sociologically, it showed that at least some American Christians live in a sort of mirror world that’s exactly like the secular world except it’s all about Jesus. So a kid can go to Christian schools that will teach Christian math and Christian biology, and play Christian video games, and listen to Christian grunge and Christian emo, and go to Christian music festivals and Christian haunted houses at Halloween. . . precisely like his counterparts in the secular world, except with everything branded as “Christian”. And while M88 did relieve tedium on long drives, I was never moved to seek out any of the artists I heard. EDIT: And I forgot to mention: Old hymns can be beautiful—”Oh! For A Thousand Tongues To Sing”, or “Come, Thou Fount Of Every Blessing”, or “There Is A Balm In Gilead”, or “Guide Me, O Thou Great Jehovah”. . . . On the other hand: “Praise songs,” or anything that involves raising your hands in the air? Barf.

This all depends on how broadly we’re defining “Christian music.” Classic hymns certainly fit, and I don't mind a select few of them. Classical music or opera, which often was written to express religious themes? I like quite a few. Contemporary music with religious overtones but no specific Christian message? Certainly, especially if we're talking about Johnny Cash or the older U2, even some Flyleaf and Jars of Clay. But actual Christian music? Like the put your hands into the air and your heart into the prayer kind of music? I don't see any point to it. Some of it doesn't make me puke, but why would anyone not believing identify with a song about belief? And hell, I say this even though I'm pretty sure I still know all the words to Jesus Freak. It's the same reason I don't enjoy rap music about money, drugs and anonymous hookups—it just doesn't have anything to do with the way I do or want to live my life. Oh, and on all counts, Creed and Sandi Patty are the worst things Christians have ever done to music, and you should all be ashamed!

I’ve written before about the Indian version of secularism. One aspect of it was that my school, with 99% Hindu students, celebrated Christmas Eve every year by decorating the corridors with paper cut-outs of holly and Christmas trees, little stars of David and angels. We would be treated to a half hour-long play by our fellow students enacting the story of Mary and Joseph and the three kings who visited the baby Jesus in his manger in Bethlehem. Interspersed were the beautiful carols from our student choir.. “Silent Night, Holy Night...” “We Three Kings of Orient are..” Every one of us knew and loved these songs. They were spiritually uplifting. A good man was born, and the world celebrated his birth. And then we would have a speech that talked about the values of Christianity. Charity. Bearing good-will to your fellow human beings. About how ’twas a season of joy, of hope, introspection, family, prayer and love. Then more choir songs.. “A holly jolly Christmas…” “It’s beginning to look a lot like Christmas…” Followed by the story of a certain reindeer.. “You know Dasher and Dancer and Prancer and Vixen…” We were children and a finale with Santa was inevitable. The fattest lad in eight grade squeezed into the red costume of that beloved midnight marauder and handed out presents to kindergartners from a huge red sack. He danced around the audience, and the choir rang out.. “You better watch out, you better not cry…” As a non-Christian (atheist, actually), I can safely say Christmas carols are a form of Christian music I deeply enjoy.

As a non-Christian, do you like Christian music? As someone who used to listen to Christian music in his teens when he was still a practicing Christian, I will say that there are some songs that I still enjoy, mainly because they have a pleasant melody. Since becoming an agnostic atheist however, I do find a lot of the lyrics to be cringeworthy. But a couple Christian music songs that I still enjoy include:  Show You Love - Jars of Clay  Breakfast Song - Newsboys  Colored People - DC Talk - This one has a pretty universal message too.  Be of Good Cheer - Petra And of course is this cover of U2’s Sunday Bloody Sunday by Christian band Pillar, that I actually like more than the original.

Good Christian music, absolutely, but none of this Jars of Clay, DC Talk, “Butterfly Kisses” dogshit. I recently wrote an entire answer dedicated to the wonders of Christian music over the centuries, from the medieval period up to the modern day. From Hildegard von Bingen’s Columba aspexit to Pergolesi’s Stabat mater to Aretha Franklin’s Amazing Grace to whatever the Blind Boys of Alabama and Mavis Staples might be up to, “I belong to the band, hallelu,” as the Reverend Gary Davis would say. For a little YouTube tour through transhistorical sublimities, see Michael Masiello's answer to Can atheists like Christian music? I am an atheist and I love a lot of Christian music: dcTalk, Relient K, Switchfoot, bands like that and many more. Not only do I think the music is great, but sometimes I appreciate the lyrics. Is this okay?

Christian rock leaves me cold, and that goes double for Christian [shudder] country & western. But Baroque pieces such as Jesu, joy of man’s desiring by Bach, or obviously Handel’s Messiah, are great. I also like the older Christmas carols (Silent Night, yes; Rudolph, no), and there’s a very comforting simplicity in church hymns. You can almost always predict the intervals, and they’re not challenging to a untrained singer. I like the music of the pipe organ, whether it’s Christian or secular. The ending of Jerusalem is absolutely spine-tingling:  I’m also particularly fond of the Finlandia hymn (“Be Still My Soul”) as sung by Izzy Cooper (apologies for the video quality):

Hardcore, ardent atheist here, and here’s a shocker: I was a part-time roadie/manager/audio guy for a Christian rock band in the San Francisco area in the mid-90s. Back in my youth, I was a Stryker fan, though I now realize…they kinda sucked. On my primary Spotify playlist, I have Jars of Clay, Creed, and Skillet (I also have EVERYTHING Collective Soul…marginally Christian, but it’s there). I like good music. A lot of Christian stuff is bad, bad music…like, horrible…but if it’s good, I’ll give it a listen!

On the whole, not really. There are a few exceptions though, especially if you loosely interpret Christian Music to include music that is written by Christian artists, but that’s cheating! My favourite Christian Band is Stryper.  This criminally underrated group tried to unite two peoples who hate each other under a common flag of black and yellow. Metalheads and any sort of religious types rarely get along, but Stryper forced the issue. While touring with Anthrax (a massive name in metal in case you’re unaware) they once decided to throw bibles into the crowd, to much uh… let’s say criticism. There is a phrase used in the heavy metal community to describe daring acts of not giving a shit about what people think of you such as this; “Metal as fuck”. These blokes are just that. For a more in-depth look at the band; check out Razor’s view on the subject. The guy knows his stuff, and is a total badass;  There’s also a music genre called Unblack Metal, but I’ll leave that investigation to you, should you wish to undertake such a journey.

I’m anti-religious and I despise all religions equally but I do enjoy Stryper. Although I don’t care about the message behind their songs but nevertheless I do agree that they sound good and in live shows they are one of the tightest sounding band. Michael Sweet is an excellent vocalist and what’s even more commendable is the way he has maintained his vocals.   Other than them I also like the first three albums of Mortification, they are a Christian Extreme Metal band, and I have to admit they were indeed an excellent Death/Thrash Metal band. But the quality of their albums after “Post Momentary Affliction” went down the gutter. They changed their vocal style from Death/Thrash grunts and rasps to weak sounding groove metal and punk style vocals, they switched from playing dirty and dark sounding Death/Thrash to groovy nu-metal like garbage. In simple words they utterly ruined those albums.

Will inscribing a pentacle around myself keep me safe from Christian pop? Others have recommended some great things - I’d like to put a word in for this:  (I find Ray Nance’s solo violin paraphrase that follows this even more astonishing.) I love the music of the Church of England, from which I parted company a long time ago. Here’s a haunting, enigmatic fifteenth century thing in a twentieth century setting by the unsurpassably named Boris Ord…  Spot the connection with this (coming up) - think very hard…(Setting by the fascinating Elizabeth Poston, an unlikely friend of EM Forster who lived near her.)  On a roll now. Here’s a setting of an ancient New Year Carol by Benjamin Britten (a ferocious Brahms-hater, by the way).  Whoever put Ralph Vaughan Williams in charge of the music for The English Hymnal knew what he was about. Its predecessor, Hymns Ancient and Modern, has a fair amount of dead wood in it… but it also has things like this…  Evangelical folk… does it strike you as odd that people like Duke Ellington and Benjamin Britten (who both did lots of things that I assume you wouldn’t consider compatible with Christian living) can convey such a sense of the transcendent and the perfect - and do so infinitely better than any ensemble of solid, prayerful purveyors of Christian dadrock? (My fondness for the linked-things above in no way prevents me from revering Frank Zappa, of course.)

YES. I love Christian rock. I love Christmas Carols. I love Bach and Mozart. I love Gregorian Chants. Oh, if it wasn’t for the whole God thing, I’d be an amazing Christian.  This is the theme song for the Holy Temple in Jerusalem, I love this song. I love the fervor, the joy.  My favorite Christmas carol.  Another favorite song.  Was this how the Levites sounded in choir?  Or was this? Seriously, I love Christian music. You guys have the best music and you should be proud.

yes, why not. I am a Sikh and yet enjoy the divine and peaceful melodies of Christianity. I found it as an escape when my friend first told me to listen to it. though there were several difficulties to find one in starting. But after a few months, I found a website on the internet called cmportal where I did find some cool Christian songs and that be with videos and lyrics to make it more understandable.

It depends on the music, of course. But some of it is amazingly good. I mean, from Bach’s Mass in B minor to Amazing Grace to A Love Supreme there has been a lot of great music that is explicitly Christian. On the other hand, there’s some Christian music I could happily do without.

If you’re talking about contemporary Christian music, the stuff that I momentarily hear on the radio when station surfing, then no. I find it unbearable and skip past it as quickly as possible. If you’re talking about requiem masses, Thomas Tallis, Bach, classical church music, yes of course, I love it. If it’s in Latin, I love it even more.

Good music is good music. And that’s very personal. A couple of my personal favourite Christians songs. I like the old Finnish Christian songs that are closely related to other folk music, but I like many other styles too as in the last sample. I picked only Finnish samples, though I like for example many American gospel songs, but I think that these are more interesting to present. You won’t understand the words, but they mostly wish that the Lord would help them somehow in their misery. Me, miserable:  O Christ, King of Glory:  Give me, my Lord, your comfort now:

I do like Christian music if it is good. When I was a teenager, quite a few of the top pop songs had a Christian message but if they were good, I would sing them in my head. Presumably, the author of this question believes that ‘non-Christian’ means ‘anti-Christian’, but that is not the case. Whatever is good that comes out of the Christian milieu is worth enjoying, whether music or anything else.

I'm an atheist (although I tell my mom I'm agnostic because the connotations are less negative), and I'm actually a huge fan of Christian rock bands like Skillet, Thousand Foot Krutch, and Fireflight. If the music’s good, I don't care what the message of the song is. I hate hymns, though. Sorry.

Good Christian music yes, very much, especially grand old hymns and carols like “It came upon the midnight clear” or “When through the night // The furnace fires a-roaring” or “Hills of the North rejoice” or “I bind unto myself today // The strong name of the Trinity” - but not most American gospel music.

Yes, even a lot of. I don’t distinguish music in terms of religion. Music is what makes us one. though we are from different parts of the world following different religions,taste etc but Music, music is the one which holds the power to get us connected. It Pinch the heart with its beats to make a straight tunnel to souls. Thats where the real god lies. Moreover, It is peaceful. So i myself being from a Indian Hindu family highly suggest to listen Christian music Or whatever you like as much as you can.

really depends on what type. i love old Gregorian chants and choral hymns. they’re quite soothing. i also find it a good excuse to listen to some Ecclesiastical Latin and practise translating. any other type of Christian music is 99.999999999% miss with me, though. can’t stand the preachy religiousness
I'm an atheist, and I absolutely love 16 Horsepower. He sings primarily about his beliefs, but I don't care much for his message. It's the music and his sincerity that hits me.

I am not a Christian, but I find “Amazing Grace” particularly soothing, relaxing, and as the title suggests: amazing. I first knew the song through a Cantopop song “明日恩典” by Hong Kong Singer, Joey Yung, only to realize that the song is a rearrangement of “Amazing Grace” with its lyrics written in Cantonese.  Amazing Grace
I love religious vocal music: Christian chorales, Islamic adhans, Hindu mantras. I wish we atheists had something like that.

music is something which is not related to religion. Christian music lovers will definitely listen music. now a days good Christians songs are coming and fans are showing their curiosity in christian music.
A muslim here… I like “Ave Maria” a lot. Remind me when watching Needful Things… Ah, that movie is my first step to Stephen King works.
No.
